description: A five-slide presentation with key information about Rugby.
title: All About Rugby

slides.title: Introduction to Rugby
slides.content: Rugby is a contact team sport that originated in England in the 19th century. There are two main codes: rugby union and rugby league. In both versions, points are scored by carrying or kicking an oval ball over the opponent's goal line to score a try, or by kicking the ball through goal posts. The sport is known for its physicality, requiring strength, speed, strategy, and teamwork.

slides.title: History and Origins
content: Rugby originated at Rugby School in England in 1823 when William Webb Ellis picked up the ball during a football game.
The Rugby Football Union was formed in 1871, establishing the laws of rugby union and banning professionalism.
Rugby league split from rugby union in 1895 in Northern England due to disputes over player payments.
Rugby union became professional globally in 1995, leading to the formation of the Tri Nations (now Rugby Championship).

slides.title: Rules and Gameplay
content: Rugby union teams have 15 players, rugby league has 13 players on the field at a time.
The ball can be passed sideways or backward, but forward passes are not allowed. Kicking is permitted in various forms.
A try (5 points) is scored by grounding the ball in the opponent's in-goal area. Conversions and penalties add extra points.
Tackling is a key defensive skill, but must be below shoulder height with the tackler wrapping their arms around the opponent.

slides.title: Famous Players and Records
content: Jonah Lomu (New Zealand) revolutionized wing play with his size and speed, starring in the 1995 World Cup.
Richie McCaw (New Zealand) is rugby's most capped captain with 110 wins and led the All Blacks to two World Cup victories.
Dan Carter (New Zealand) is the highest points scorer in test rugby with 1,598 points and is considered one of the greatest fly-halves.
Wales' Shane Williams is the highest try scorer in international rugby with 60 tries in his career.

slides.title: Global Impact and Competitions
content: The Rugby World Cup is held every four years and is one of the largest sporting events in the world.
The Six Nations Championship (Europe) and Rugby Championship (Southern Hemisphere) are major annual tournaments.
Rugby sevens, a faster 7-a-side version, became an Olympic sport in 2016 and has grown rapidly in popularity.
Rugby is particularly popular in New Zealand, South Africa, Australia, England, Wales, Ireland, France, and Argentina.
